net.markenwerk.utils.data.fetcher

Class Fetcher

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.markenwerk.utils.data.fetcher.Fetcher

  • public final class Fetcher
extends Object
    A convenient replacement for IOUtils.toByteArray() to perform the everyday and menial task of reading an entire InputStream into a byte[] with the method fetch(InputStream).

    Since the class sun.misc.IOUtils, which provides this functionality, is not a part of the official Java specification, usages of this class will usually yield a compiler warning like "The type 'IOUtils' is not API" and might break at runtime, if a runtime environment other than the Oracle JRE is used.

    Furthermore, this class allows to copy the content of an InputStream directly into an OutputStream, using the method fetch(InputStream, OutputStream).

    All methods take optional parameters to specify the buffer size and to specify, whether the provided streams should be closed afterwards. This allows to write compact code like 

     
 foo.setContent(Fetcher.fetch(new FileInputStream(file), true));
    instead of unnecessarily verbose code like 
     {
        @code
        InputStream in = new FileInputStream(file);
        foo.setContent(Fetcher.fetch(in));
        in.close();
 }
    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Torsten Krause (tk at markenwerk dot net)

      • fetch

        public static byte[] fetch(InputStream in)
                    throws IOException
        Copies the content of a given InputStream into a fresh byte[], using byte[] as a buffer of default buffer size of one kibibyte (1024 bytes).

        See fetch(InputStream, OutputStream, int, boolean, boolean) for the handling of missing or invalid arguments.

        Parameters:
        in - The InputStream to read from.
        Returns:
        A new byte[], containing the content of the given InputStream.
        Throws:
        IOException - If anything went wrong while reading from the given InputStream.

      • fetch

        public static byte[] fetch(InputStream in,
                           boolean close)
                    throws IOException
        Copies the content of a given InputStream into a fresh byte[], using byte[] as a buffer of default buffer size of one kibibyte (1024 bytes).

        See fetch(InputStream, OutputStream, int, boolean, boolean) for the handling of missing or invalid arguments.

        Parameters:
        in - The InputStream to read from.
        close - Whether to close the given InputStream, after reading from it.
        Returns:
        A new byte[], containing the content of the given InputStream.
        Throws:
        IOException - If anything went wrong while reading from the given InputStream. IOExceptions thrown while trying to close the given InputStream, if requested, are ignored.

        Copies the content of a given InputStream into a given OutputStream, using byte[] as a buffer of default buffer size of one kibibyte (1024 bytes).

        See fetch(InputStream, OutputStream, int, boolean, boolean) for the handling of missing or invalid arguments.

        out - The OutputStream to write to.
        Throws:
        IOException - If anything went wrong while reading from the given InputStream or writing to the given OutputStream.

      • fetch

        public static void fetch(InputStream in,
                         OutputStream out,
                         boolean closeIn,
                         boolean closeOut)
                  throws IOException
        Copies the content of a given InputStream into a given OutputStream, using byte[] as a buffer of default buffer size of one kibibyte (1024 bytes).

        See fetch(InputStream, OutputStream, int, boolean, boolean) for the handling of missing or invalid arguments.

        Parameters:
        in - The InputStream to read from.
        out - The OutputStream to write to.
        closeIn - Whether to close the given InputStream, after reading from it.
        closeOut - Whether to close the given OutputStream, after writing to it.
        Throws:
        IOException - If anything went wrong while reading from the given InputStream or writing to the given OutputStream. IOExceptions thrown while trying to close one of the given streams, if requested, are ignored.

        Throws:

      • fetch

        public static void fetch(InputStream in,
                         OutputStream out,
                         int bufferSize,
                         boolean closeIn,
                         boolean closeOut)
                  throws IOException
        Copies the content of a given InputStream into a given OutputStream, using a byte[] as a buffer.

        Missing or invalid arguments are handled gracefully with the following behaviour.

        A null is given as an InputStream, it is simply ignored and handled as if there was nothing to read. If closeOut is true, the given OutputStream will be closed anyway

        A null is given as an OutputStream, it is simply ignored, but the content of given InputStream is fetched anyway. If closeIn is true, the given InputStream will be closed anyway

        A non-positive buffer size is replaced with the default buffer size of one kibibyte (1024 bytes).

        Parameters:
        in - The InputStream to read from.
        out - The OutputStream to write to.
        bufferSize - The size of the buffer.
        closeIn - Whether to close the given InputStream, after reading from it.
        closeOut - Whether to close the given OutputStream, after writing to it.
        Throws:
        IOException - If anything went wrong while reading from the given InputStream or writing to the given OutputStream. IOExceptions thrown while trying to close one of the given streams, if requested, are ignored.
